questions.question_text:
An administrator used the Horizon Console to specify the Active Directory account for joining instant-clone VMs to the Active Directory domain.
What two permissions must be granted to the Active Directory account to perform this task? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Grant the Global Domain Administrator role.
choices.E: Grant the Horizon Domain Admin role.
choices.B: Write properties in the domain or in the organization units.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
Correct answer is B&C. Horizon Domain Admin is not a built-in role.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Horizon/2006/horizon-installation/GUID-E91881F4-F8C0-48A5-A1A4-61577E287E29.html

Selected Answer: BC
C. Create and delete computer objects.

This permission allows the Active Directory account to create and delete computer objects within the specified organizational units (OUs) in the Active Directory domain. It's essential for joining VMs to the domain.
B. Write properties in the domain or in the organization units.

This permission enables the Active Directory account to write necessary properties, such as computer object attributes, within the domain or specified organizational units where the VMs will be joined. It's crucial for managing the objects during the domain join process.

Selected Answer: BC
Because that is the fact, please correct: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Horizon-7/7.13/horizon-installation/GUID-E91881F4-F8C0-48A5-A1A4-61577E287E29.html

Selected Answer: BC
BC. Domain Admin is not needed.

B&C
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Horizon/2212/horizon-installation/GUID-E91881F4-F8C0-48A5-A1A4-61577E287E29.html#GUID-E91881F4-F8C0-48A5-A1A4-61577E287E29

Selected Answer: BC
In vmware docs...
--------------------------------
In Active Directory, create a user account in the same domain as the Connection Server or in a trusted domain.
Add the Create Computer Objects, Delete Computer Objects, and Write All Properties permissions to the account on the container for the instant-clone computer accounts.
The following list shows the required permissions for the user account, including permissions that are assigned by default:
List Contents
Read All Properties
Write All Properties
Read Permissions
Reset Password
Create Computer Objects
Delete Computer Objects
Make sure that the permissions apply to the correct container and to all child objects of the container.

Selected Answer: D
The correct diagram is B but the answer is D: B needs to be vdm for the friendly name

Selected Answer: D
Exhibit B...so answer D: friendly name must not be "vdi", but "vdm".

Selected Answer: D
As others have mentioned the friendly name must be vdm - Answer is D (Image B)

Selected Answer: D
friendly name must be vdm. correct answer is D

Selected Answer: B
wrong, shoul be B, Assign the friendly name "vdm" to only one certificate on each VMware Horizon server host.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

An administrator configures a CA certificate for the Connection Server. However, they are still encountering certificate warnings when trying to connect to the
Connection Server. The exhibit displays the properties of the CA-Signed certificate.
Referring to the exhibit and using the alpha-character indicator, which image shows the root cause of the issue?

A user is assigned two writable volumes, one created using a Windows 7 and another using a Windows 10 machine.
Which of the following scenarios will happen when the user logs on to a Windows 10 VM?

discussion.content: D es la respuesta. https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-App-Volumes/2206/app-volumes-admin-guide/GUID-B527414C-C0DC-4096-89E8-D4E192C4131D.html

Selected Answer: D
One writable volume per machine. If the volume was created with a machine OS prefix it can only be attached to that OS.
In theory the user could have an active session on win10 with the win10 volume while at the same time have a session on a windows 7 VM with the win7 volume attached.
Agree D

Selected Answer: D
A user can have more than one Writable Volume attached at the same time if the volume is OS-specific, or created for a computer with a specific prefix. For example, suppose that you create a Writable Volume for each of the following:
A Windows 7 machine
A Windows 10 machine
A computer with Win2012-dev prefix to its name
A computer with Win2012-test prefix to its name
Then, when the user logs in to these different machines at the same time, each Writable Volume that is assigned to the specific machine is attached to the user at the same time.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-App-Volumes/2206/app-volumes-admin-guide/GUID-B527414C-C0DC-4096-89E8-D4E192C4131D.html

Combine that with the fact that a virtual machine can have only one Writable Volume attached to the virtual machine at a given time.

Selected Answer: D
A virtual machine can have only one writable volume attached at any given time and the matching version will take priority. So D

I think answer is D:- 

A virtual machine can have only one Writable Volume attached to the virtual machine at a given time.
A Writable Volume can be attached only to a single virtual machine at a given time.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-App-Volumes/2206/app-volumes-admin-guide/GUID-B527414C-C0DC-4096-89E8-D4E192C4131D.html

choices.A: Both writable volumes gets attached to the Windows 10 machine.
choices.B: Since a machine can have only one Writable Volume attached to it at a given point in time, and the user has two assigned writable volumes, none of them gets attached.
choices.D: The writable volume created using a using Windows 10 machine gets attached.
choices.C: Since a machine can have only one Writable Volume attached to it at a given point in time, the user cannot have two assigned writable volumes.

questions.question_text: Which two databases are supported in Horizon 8 for Event Database configuration? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Horizon/2206/horizon-installation/GUID-BB44ADF4-5B1E-48C2-ACD1-789034488A2F.html

choices.B: The Horizon Event Database is not configured.
choices.C: The Windows Event Viewer is disabled.
choices.A: The Timing Profiler is disabled on the Connection server.
choices.D: The VMware Horizon Logon Monitor service is not started.

questions.question_text:
An end-user complains that their logon time has increased dramatically. An administrator opens the VMware Logon Monitor log folder to troubleshoot the issue, but it does not contain logfiles for the reported session.
What could be the cause of this issue?

discussion.content:
The correct answer is D.
When the Horizon Agent is installed, the VMware Login Monitor service defaults to manual. You must change the startup type to automatic. 
The user logon segments are not sent to the Horizon Events log but if the timing profiler on the connection servers is enabled, you will see the segments in the Helpdesk Tool.

https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/57051

Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is D.

Selected Answer: D
hello please vote, D, When the Horizon Agent is installed, the VMware Login Monitor service defaults to manual. You must change the startup type to automatic.

Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is D

https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/77099

https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/57051
